entry.et: Middle English sumer, from Old English sumor; akin to Old High German & Old Norse sumer summer, Sanskrit samā year, season

def.dt: :the season between spring and autumn comprising in the northern hemisphere usually the months of June, July, and August or as reckoned astronomically extending from the June solstice to the September equinox
:of, relating to, or suitable for summer summer vacation a summer home
:sown in the spring and harvested in the same year as sown summer wheat compare winter
:to keep or carry through the summer
:to provide (as cattle or sheep) with pasture during the summer
:a densely branched Eurasian herb (Kochia scoparia) of the goosefoot family grown for its foliage which turns red in autumn
:a greenish-brown white-spotted flounder (Paralichthys dentatus of the family Bothidae) that occurs along the Atlantic coast of the United States from Maine to Florida and is used for food
:a small building or shed that is usually adjacent to a house and is used as a kitchen in warm weather
:an aromatic annual European mint (Satureja hortensis) with leaves used for seasoning

:a school or school session conducted in summer enabling students to accelerate progress toward a diploma or degree, to make up credits lost through absence or failure, or to round out professional education
:any of various squashes that are cultivars of a variety (Cucurbita pepo var. melopepo) and are used as a vegetable while immature and before hardening of the seeds and rind
:theatrical productions of stock companies presented during the summer
